data.name: Try and Give me 5
data.description:
It's the 5th of May in Pentapolys and all folks there use to celebrate their National Day.

Each year, a coding contest is launched after the royal parade.

This time, the Fifth Minister will ask all would-be players to build a function ```gimmefive() ```, which is passed a certain ```function fn()``` as its argument and it is supposed to return the same exact `fn` function.

```javascript 
function gimmefive(fn) {
  return fn;
}
```

The judges should be able to call ```gimmefive(anyFunctionJudgesLike)``` by passing a particular function they want to. Then, they expect to get 5 from invoking the returned function:

```javascript
const mustGiveFive = gimmefive(() => "lustra live the Queen!");
const five = mustGiveFive();
five === 5; // must be true
```

Needless to say, the solution has to respect the mentioned requirement for this task, which means the returned function must be the same as the one passed:

```javascript
// passing() and returned() ought to be the same function
const passing = () => 5;
const returned = gimmefive(passing);

```

Sir V. — a trusted adviser of the Queen — has clarified that the elected function `anyFunctionJudgesLike` has a consistent behavior and it will not be changed throughout the celebration day.

Remember that people out there are really sensitive about their culture of fiveness.

Since this event is likely to get a high coverage on all Pentapolyan media, the National Security 5ervice "recommended" smoothing things out a little bit, as a way to let people have more fun and avoid any possible riot.

In an attempt to reassure all of her subjects, the Queen herself is due to deliver a speech solemnly assuring ```"there shall be no hidden nor random tests on the mathematical aspects of the matter for today"```.

While revising the guidelines for this match, though, the appointed committee warned that some concern may arise from a rule under Section 125e, which states:

```javascript
const e125 = `  In order to guarantee a fair game,
              all players involved in a royal contest
              launched for the National Day MUST NOT
              manipulate any standard Function that might
              provoke any side effects on other coders.

                Transgressors will be prosecuted 
              under the law of the Reign of Pentapolys. `;
```

This being said, it's 4.30 a.m. local time and in a few hours Pentapolys will celebrate the most important day of the year. All eyes are on the kingdom.

As you know, the Secretary of the Queen has just rung you up some minutes ago.

Her Majesty needs YOU! What a pleasure must be.

**You are now Her Majesty's First Official Coder in charge**, therefore you are *invited to supervise some of the challenges* after the parade.

Yeah, that probably means they want to smuggle any working code from you.

Should the royal contest go wrong, deployed agents in plain clothes will submit your operating solution to save the celebration.

Be honored, it's for the safety of the Fiveness!
